meta.content: Find news & music reviews on singers, songwriters, bands, classical music, concerts, albums, symphony, Grammy Awards, MTV, videos, musicians, Rock & Roll Hall of Fame & CDs.

img.alt: New York Times

div.p: Friday, September 4, 2009

h3.a: Culture Fans, It’s Not Too Late for Summer Fun

div.p: Critics and reporters of The New York Times have some suggestions for ways to make the Labor Day weekend entertaining.

li.a: It’s Not Too Late for Grooving

h3.a: It’s Not Too Late for Grooving

div.p: Here are Labor Day weekend suggestions by music critics and reporters of The New York Times.

img.alt: Family and guests arrived for Michael Jackson's entombment in a private mausoleum at Forest Lawn Memorial Park in Glendale, Calif., on Thursday.

h3.a: In a Private Service, Last Goodbyes for Jackson

div.h6: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD 2:09 AM ET
div.p: Michael Jackson was entombed Thursday night at a highly guarded mausoleum in a Los Angeles suburb.

h3.a: A Night of Remakes and Roots by the River

div.p: Mr. Fogerty reached back to a mythic rural America by performing down-home sounds with a thread of environmentalism at the South Street Seaport on Wednesday.

h3.a: A Weekend for Floating on the East River

div.p: Bargemusic is offering music from its inventive Here and Now series this weekend. Wednesday’s program featured works by David Shohl, Elizabeth Adams and Russell Platt.

div.h6: Music Review | Throw Me the Statue, The Brunettes

h3.a: Singing Sharp Lyrics While Guitars Hazily Strum

div.p: Both groups made use of electronic drum tracks and reverb, and both played songs with sharp-witted lyrics that unraveled a bit on closer inspection at the Mercury Lounge on Wednesday.

img.alt: Jane Scheckter and Tom Hubbard performing on Tuesday.

h3.a: Her Eyes Wide Open, Her Feet on the Ground

div.p: Jane Scheckter goes back to the source, drawing from both pre-rock songwriters and pop-jazz swing in her new cabaret act at the Metropolitan Room.

img.alt: From left, John Surman, Drew Gress, John Abercrombie and Jack DeJohnette at Birdland.

h3.a: Humble Headliner With a History

div.p: The multireedist John Surman provided a full but focused sound on baritone saxophone with his quartet at Birdland on Tuesday.

img.alt: Angélica Negrón playing accordion in one of her own works.

h3.a: When Composers Provide Full Service, Supplying Both the Music and the Players

div.p: By having so many players at the service of five composers, the organization’s concert at Le Poisson Rouge on Tuesday was an inefficient but luxurious display of music.

img.alt: Trey Songz performing at the Highline Ballroom on Tuesday night in Manhattan.

h3.a: He May Not Have Invented Sex, but He Sure Does Like to Sing About It

div.p: The question wasn’t if Trey Songz would strip down Tuesday night at the Highline Ballroom, but when.

img.alt: Marie Knight at the Bottom Line in New York in 2003.

h3.a: Marie Knight, Rich-Voiced Gospel Singer, Dies at 89

div.p: Ms. Knight’s room-filling contralto voice was featured on some of the most popular gospel records of the 1940s.

img.alt: Colbie Caillat’s second album, “Breakthrough,” is a major hit.

h3.a: Singing a (Very) Simple Song

div.p: The female duo that best captures the pop moment is Colbie Caillat and Ingrid Michaelson. The nice girls are back in control — how did this come to pass?

h3.a: Those Who Paved the Way for Bach

div.p: The 4x4 Baroque Music Festival, directed by the harpsichordist Avi Stein and now in its second season, is offered as a period-instrument fancier’s farewell to summer.

img.alt: The pixelated Paul McCartney, left, and George Harrison in their mop top period, in The Beatles: Rock Band.

h3.a: All Together Now: Play the Game, Mom

div.p: The Beatles: Rock Band reinterprets an essential symbol of one generation in the medium and technology of another.

img.alt: West 73rd, a jazz quartet, performed the music of Kurt Weill on Sunday at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency.

h3.a: Jazzy Variations on Kurt Weill’s Themes

div.p: West 73rd, which performed at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency on Sunday, takes songs, mostly from Weill’s American period, and turns them into classically informed jazz pieces.

h3.a: Trills and Thrills

div.p: Why do some people’s singing voices have more vibrato than others? Can it be taught?

img.alt: Chris Connor at the club Sweet Basil in 1981.

h3.a: Chris Connor, Jazz Singer Whose Voice Embodied a Wistful Cool, Dies at 81

div.p: Ms. Connor was the great jazz singer whose lush, foggy voice and compressed emotional intensity distilled a 1950s jazz reverie of faraway longing in a sad cafe.

img.alt: Erich Kunzel conducting the Cincinnati Pops Orchestra.

h3.a: Erich Kunzel, Maestro With an Irreverent Baton, Dies at 74

div.p: The conductor of the Cincinnati Pops Orchestra for more than three decades, Mr.Kunzel was known for undermining the pretensions of symphonic music.

img.alt: Whitney Houston

h3.a: Earning Diva Cred With Storm and Stress

div.p: Whitney Houston re-emerges with full diva qualifications on “I Look to You.” Plus, new releases from Datarock and Richard Hell & the Voidoids.

div.h6: Music Review | Charlie Parker Jazz Festival

img.alt: Frank Wess, center, with the guitarist Ilya Lushtak and Scott Robinson. Mr. Wess’s set was grounded in 1940s and ’50s grammar.

h3.a: Connecting Dots, From Bird to Michael Jackson

div.p: The long wave of this summer’s Michael Jackson tributes rolled through the annual Charlie Parker Jazz Festival.

h3.a: The Pianist Is Casual in All Things but Music

div.p: Mr. Denk, a thoughtful pianist who has always seemed most at home in early-19th-century repertory, turns out to have broader tastes.

h3.a: Lots of Neo-Romanticism, Emphasis on the Neo

div.p: Neo-Romantic string works were the order of the day, the group’s stylistic independence notwithstanding.

h3.a: Buju Banton Shows Canceled After Protests

div.p: Live Nation and AEG have canceled shows by Buju Banton, the Jamaican reggae singer whose violent homophobic lyrics have drawn protests.

h3.a: A Symphony on Sale

div.p: The American Symphony Orchestra is offering $25 tickets for any seat at any performance in its 2009-10 “Great Performers” series at Avery Fisher Hall.

h3.a: Pssst! Want a Ticket? Hey, I’m Legit. Really.

div.p: The world of scalpers becomes more transparent, more entrepreneurial and more Byzantine.

img.alt: Sophie Tucker in 1909. Her earliest recordings are being released on CD.

h3.a: A Century Later, She’s Still Red Hot

div.p: A new anthology of her earliest recordings shows that Sophie Tucker, at the peak of her stardom, was anything but old-fashioned.

h3.a: A ‘Ring’ Recording That Has It All (Except the Music)

div.p: A solo reading of Wagner’s epic cycle, including the stage directions, in the voice of a storyteller.

img.alt: Bach on some novelty instruments: Pius Cheung, whose version of the “Goldberg” Variations is billed as the first recording of that work on marimba.

h3.a: Bach’s ‘Goldberg’ as You’ve Never Heard It

div.p: Since Glenn Gould’s landmark recording, Bach’s “Goldberg” variations have been interpreted by many others. Now, two harpists and a marimba player have entered the fray.

img.alt: Robert Glasper

h3.a: Chanting, Jazzy, Beachy, Funky, Lonely Sounds

div.p: Reviews of releases by the Drums, Bloody Panda, Robert Glasper, Mount Eerie and Klang.

img.alt: PLAY FOR PAY The jazz pianist Cedar Walton at Dizzy’s Club Coca-Cola before his second set on a Sunday night.

h3.a: The Piano’s Pull, Day and Night

div.p: For the jazz pianist Cedar Walton, Sundays start slowly and eventually lead to a banana, the comics, some music and perhaps a three-minute swordfish.

img.alt: AySel & Arash, Azerbaijan's entry into the 2009 Eurovision song contest, performed in Moscow in May.

h3.a: A Song Contest Becomes a Hot Spot in Feud Between Countries

div.p: The simmering conflict between Armenia and Azerbaijan has moved into the Eurovision Song Contest.

h3.a: A Bigger Setting for a Musical Stew

div.p: The family-friendly Union County MusicFest, a free weekend-long event, lures baby boomer and stroller brigade with artists like Chuck Berry and Dan Zanes.

img.alt: Taylor Swift performed for two hours in front of a predominantly young and female audience at Madison Square Garden on Thursday night.

h3.a: She’s a Little Bit Country, a Little Bit Angry

div.p: Taylor Swift, the 19-year-old country pop songwriter, headlined a sold-out concert at Madison Square Garden on Thursday night.

h3.a: Noel Gallagher Says He’s Leaving Oasis

div.p: The lead guitarist of the British rock band Oasis, says he’s leaving the band because he can’t work “a day longer” with his brother Liam, The Associated Press reported.

h3.a: Jackson’s Death Ruled a Homicide

div.p: A mixture of the powerful anesthetic propofol and the anti-anxiety drug lorazepam killed Michael Jackson, according to the Los Angeles County Coroner Office.

ul.li: Times Topics: Michael Jackson | Conrad Murray

img.alt: Joseph D’Agostino of the band Cymbals Eat Guitars at Brooklyn Bowl on Thursday.

h3.a: The Ecstatic Passion of Indie Rock Grows in Brooklyn

div.p: Insound, the Brooklyn music distributor and online retailer, sponsored a five-band show of new indie rock at Brooklyn Bowl in Williamsburg on Thursday night.

h3.a: Ardent Dialogue for Piano and Cello

div.p: The cellist Zuill Bailey and the pianist Simone Dinnerstein performed at Le Poisson Rouge on Thursday to celebrate their new release of Beethoven works.

div.h6: Music Review | Marc Ribot’s Sun Ship

h3.a: Questing After Coltrane’s Messy Transcendence

div.p: The dauntless, combustible energies of jazz’s 1960s avant-garde have long held a deep attraction for the guitarist Marc Ribot.

img.alt: Bartlett Sher’s staging of Rossini’s “Barbiere di Siviglia,” shown in movie theaters as a live, high-definition video program, will be rebroadcast in the Metropolitan Opera’s free Summer HD Festival.

h3.a: It’s Not Over Till the HD Video Is Screened

div.p: The Metropolitan Opera is offering outdoor broadcasts from past seasons to whet opera appetites.

a.img: Videos: The Metropolitan Opera in HD

img.alt: Michael Sample directing the choir of the Ganesha Temple in Flushing, Queens. A temple choir is a rarity in Hinduism.

h3.a: Old Faith Innovates in a New Land

div.p: While a newly formed choir at the Ganesha Temple in Queens met initial resistance, the singers plan to become a fixture there. But first, they have to expand their repertoire.

a.img: Slide Show: Hindu Choir Debuts in Queens

h6.a: Keeping Radio’s Salsa Hot for 50 Years
Music Review: Self-Generated Energy Fuels Go-for-Broke Improvisation
Music Review| Neal Smith Group: Gently, Gently, a Drummer Leads His Pack
Music Review: Roll Over, Beethoven: Here’s Rock You’d Like
A&E Plans Reality Series on Jacksons
Music Review: Building on Bach, Drawing on Debussy
Music: An Opera Can Take Its Time, or Yours
Music Review: A Metal Powerhouse, Screaming Farewell for Now
Court Papers Show Jackson Died of Propofol
John E. Carter, Doo-Wop Falsetto, Dies at 75
Larry Knechtel, Rock Keyboardist-Arranger, Dies at 69

img.alt: Arts Beat

div.p: September 3, 2009

h5.a: Record Labels Say Student Is Still Encouraging Illegal Downloads

div.p: September 3, 2009

h5.a: Colbie Caillat Bubbles Up to Top of Chart

div.p: September 2, 2009

p.a: More Music News in Arts Beat »

div.p: The teenage country pop songwriter performed before an adoring multitude at Madison Square Garden.

img.alt: Woodstock: A Look Back

div.p: Jon Pareles on three days of peace and music, remembered, beloved and commodified 40 years later.

ul.li: Reader Videos: Woodstock Memories | Submit a Video

li.img: Slide Shows: New York Times Photographers | Readers' Photos

a.img: Audio Slide Show: A Photographer Remembers

img.alt: Timeline: 1969 in Popular Culture

div.p: The music, movies and events that seemed to sum up the chaos, creativity, violence and hopefulness of the decade.

img.alt: Podcast: Music

h3.a: Podcast: Music

div.p: Jon Pareles, chief pop music critic, moderates a round table about Woodstock at 40. Joining him are three reporters who braved the mud and the music for The Times in 1969: Michael Kaufman, Barnard Collier and Mike Jahn. Sia Michel is the host.

div.h6: The Life and Death of Michael Jackson

h5.a: The Passing of a Pop Icon

div.p: Michael Jackson, the legendary singer, songwriter and dancer, died in Los Angeles on Thursday.

h5.a: What Is Your Favorite Michael Jackson Song?

div.p: Choose from among eight of Mr. Jackson’s biggest hits, with commentary by Sia Michel, The Times’s pop music editor.

img.alt: Bring Out Your Dead

h3.a: Bring Out Your Dead

p.p: The canon of Grateful Dead shows was built over 20-something years of the band’s existence, and is still developing.
